title: How one Fijian luxury resort has stayed on top for 40 years
text:
Ute Junker Travel writer Sep 4, 2019 — 10.05am Share

You can crunch the numbers on “room nights”, calculate the daily spend or track your social media mentions. Landi Burns, however, has her own ways of measuring the success of her resort. Among other things, she keeps an eye on how often she has to order new Monopoly sets.

“We have to replace them a lot, they get used so much,” she says happily. “To me, that’s what it is all about.”

Board games are not usually considered the cutting-edge of luxury. But at Turtle Island, the Fijian hideaway which Burns manages with her husband Rob, they do things differently. At this top-tier resort, which has deliberately chosen not to offer in-room Wi-Fi, board games have become one indicator of how guests are unwinding.

Doing nothing is by far the most popular activity on Turtle Island.

“This place is about disconnecting to reconnect,” Burns says, explaining why the resort has resisted pressure to provide unfettered access to Wi-Fi. “People come to connect: with their partner, with the staff, with other guests.” Instead of gazing into their phones, Burns want guests to get involved, whether it’s a game of Monopoly or something else. “Listen to the birds, go for a swim, read a book, talk to your partner.”

It is an unusual approach, but Turtle Island has always done things its own way. Four decades after American entrepreneur Richard Evanson opened this private island to paying guests, it remains one of Fiji’s premier hideaways. The idyllic location in the Yasawa Islands is one obvious attraction; so are the all-inclusive rate and limited guest numbers – there are just 14 sprawling bures on an island that has 12 private beaches. Other aspects of the experience are, well, unexpected.

While contemporary resorts are usually designed to encourage cocooning, providing ever-more extravagant villas in which guests can hide away, Turtle Island takes a different tack. Here, meals have always been served communally at one long table and the only menu you will ever see is at breakfast, when you can choose between ever-changing options such as Indian spiced eggs, shrimp omelette or parfait cinnamon yoghurt with papaya compote. Lunch features shared platters, while dinner is a set three-course feast. In the mood for a romantic evening for two? Staff will set you up at one of a number of private dining locations, perhaps on a beach or atop a cliff.

By contrast, Fiji’s newer resorts – including recent openings such as Lang Walker’s Kokomo and the South Pacific’s first Six Senses resort – have taken a more indulgent approach, with villas kitted out with private pools and on-trend touches such as kombucha cocktails, gluten-free bakeries and open-air cinemas.

Life on Turtle Island is somewhat simpler. Guests can go snorkelling and horse riding or savour a spa treatment, but by far the most popular activity is doing nothing much: just hanging out in the alfresco bar, on the loungers and hammocks in front of the bures, or on a private beach (each equipped with a sign that can be flipped from Vacant to Occupied to warn off others).
description: Turtle Island has turned relaxation into an unusual fine art that’s been luring guests for four decades.
